docs.title: Welcome to Linux Commands Documentation
docs.text: This project aims to document various Linux commands with detailed descriptions, examples, and use cases.

docs.title: About
docs.text: This documentation is hosted on GitHub Pages and generated using MkDocs.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The cp command is used to copy files and directories in Linux. It creates a duplicate of the specified file or directory at a different location.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
cp [options] source destination
  • source: The file or directory you want to copy.
  • destination: The location where you want to copy the file or directory.

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• -r or -R: Recursively copy directories and their contents.
  • -v: Verbose mode, showing the files being copied.
  • -i: Interactive mode, prompts before overwriting files.
  • -u: Copy only when the source file is newer than the destination file or when the destination file is missing.
  • -f: Force the copy by removing the destination file if it exists.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
• Basic File Copy: To copy a file from one location to another:
cp file.txt /home/user/documents/

This command copies file.txt to the /home/user/documents/ directory. - Copy a Directory: To copy an entire directory and its contents:

cp -r /home/user/documents /home/user/backup/

This command copies the documents directory and all its contents to the backup directory.

  • Verbose Mode: To see the files being copied:
cp -v file.txt /home/user/documents/

docs.title: Example output
docs.text:
'file.txt' -> '/home/user/documents/file.txt'
  • Interactive Mode: To prompt before overwriting files:
cp -i file.txt /home/user/documents/

Confirmation will be asked before overwriting any existing files.

  • Copy Only Newer Files: To copy only if the source file is newer than the destination file:
cp -u file.txt /home/user/documents/

docs.title: ls Command
docs.text: The ls command in Linux is used to list the contents of a directory. It provides information about files and directories, such as their names, permissions, sizes, and timestamps. The command has various options that allow users to customize the output.

docs.title: Basic Syntax
docs.text:
ls [OPTION]... [FILE]...
  • OPTION: Flags that modify the behavior of the command.
  • FILE: The directory or file to list. If no file is provided, ls defaults to the current directory.

docs.title: Commonly Used Options
docs.text:
• -l: Displays the contents in a long listing format, which includes details like permissions, number of links, owner, group, size, and timestamp.
ls -l

Example Output:

-rw-r--r-- 1 user user 1234 Aug 27 08:00 example.txt
  • -a: Lists all files, including hidden files (those starting with a dot .).
ls -a

Example output:

.  ..  .bashrc  .profile  example.txt
  • -h: Makes file sizes human-readable (e.g., K, M, G).
ls -lh

Example Output:

-rw-r--r-- 1 user user 1.2K Aug 27 08:00 example.txt
  • -R: Lists directories and their contents recursively.
ls -R

Example Output:

.:
dir1  file1.txt

./dir1:
file2.txt
  • -t: sorts the output by modification time, newest first.
ls -lt

example output:

-rw-r--r-- 1 user user 1234 aug 27 08:00 latest_file.txt
-rw-r--r-- 1 user user 5678 aug 26 15:45 older_file.txt

docs.title: advanced usage
docs.text:
• combine options: Multiple options can be combined to refine output.
ls -lha

This command lists all files, including hidden ones, in a long format with human-readable sizes.

  • Listing a specific directory: To list the contents of a specific directory, provide the directory name as an argument.
ls -l /home/user/Documents
  • Filter by file type: Use wildcards to filter by file types.
ls *.txt

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The pwd (print working directory) command is used to display the current working directory in the terminal. It shows the full path from the root directory to your current directory.

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• -L: Prints the logical current working directory, resolving any symbolic links.
  • -P: Prints the physical current working directory, with all symbolic links resolved.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
• Basic Usage: To simply display our current directory
pwd

docs.title: Example Output
docs.text:
/home/user/projects
  • -L: If current directory is a symbolic link, and want to display the logical path:
pwd -L
  • -P: To display the physical path, resolving any symbolic links:
pwl -P
